Stephen thank you for writing up this comprehensive guide! Quick question, if I wanted to develop a very simple distributed system (i.e. computing a 'calculation' on 'n' computers'), where robustness is more important than performance, would you suggest using WCF or go with the TcpClient/Socket approach? Time is also fairly limited.

"very simple distributed system" - not sure if that exists. ;)

I'd say that neither WCF nor plain sockets are best. I'd first recommend using a prebuilt solution, something like Azure HPC or Dryad. If you really do need to write your own, I'd suggest self-hosted SignalR/

Hello Stephen. Thanks for this FAQ. Verifies some of my suspicions. I wonder if you know a solid framework to send strings beetwen two UWP apps. ( Hololens / Tablet ). I looked at SignalR but the Serverpart can't be run on an UWP app yet.

Hi Stephen, ive read a lot of your articles and you clear things up with aplomb (turtles all the way...) Can I ask, this day and age is it best to use websockets or sockets, as websockets get around the framing issue. Thanks Martin

I answer socket communication questions on SO fairly regularly, and I *always* recommend using SignalR or WebSockets if possible.

However, there are still many scenarios where using TCP sockets is necessary. Embedded devices, co-vendors, and existing protocols are the most common scenarios. It's safe to say we'll always have raw TCP sockets with us.

I have a talk on TCP/IP protocol design that I submit to all kinds of tech conferences. Unfortunately, only one has ever accepted it. I think it is the best-attended talk I've ever had (after scaling for conference size(. Standing room only, people out in the hallway straining to hear. So I find it really curious that no other tech conference has ever accepted that talk. Well, I'm bad at writing abstracts, so that's probably why. Anyway, all that to say that even though I start that talk (and my SO answers) with some form of "use SignalR/WebSockets if at all possible", there are still lots of developers who still need to communicate over plain old TCP/IP for some inescapable reason or another.
